items.description:
These frameworks make customizing your ZSH setup easier.
You can find performance timing comparisons of various frameworks in the following locations.
Contains performance benchmarks for the most popular ZSH frameworks, including both install time and load time.
items.title: rossmacarthur/zsh-plugin-manager-benchmark

items.description: Tooling for running performance tests on multiple ZSH frameworks.
items.title: pm-perf-test
Frameworks

items.description: Alf is an out of this world super fast and configurable framework for ZSH; it's modeled after Prezto and Antigen while utilizing Oh-My-Zsh under the covers; and offers standard defaults, aliases, functions, auto completion, automated updates and installable prompt themes and plugins.
items.title: alf

items.description: ansible-role-zsh is an ansible role with zero-knowledge installation. It uses antigen to manage bundles and oh-my-zsh. Can load bundles conditionally. By default it includes the powerlevel9k theme, autosuggestions, syntax-highlighting and fzf-widgets and fzf-marks. Fully customizable.
items.title: ansible-role-zsh

items.description: Ant-zsh is a tiny and lightweight ZSH configuration environment for special customization needs. It includes plugins, themes and a basic convenient setup.
items.title: ant-zsh

items.description: Antibody is a faster and simpler antigen written in Golang. More details are available at http://getantibody.github.io/.
items.title: antibody

items.description:
Antidote is a ZSH plugin manager made from the ground up thinking about performance.
It is fast because it can do things concurrently, and generates an ultra-fast static plugin file that you can include in your ZSH config.
It is written natively in ZSH, is well tested, and picks up where Antibody left off.
use-omz enables easy use of Oh-My-ZSH with antidote.
items.title: antidote

items.description: antigen-hs is a replacement for antigen optimized for a low overhead when starting up a session. It will automatically clone plugins for you.
items.title: antigen-hs

items.description: Antigen is a small set of functions that help you easily manage your shell (ZSH) plugins, called bundles. The concept is pretty much the same as bundles in a typical vim+pathogen setup. Antigen is to ZSH, what Vundle is to . Antigen can load oh-my-zsh themes and plugins and will automatically clone them for you.
items.title: antigen

items.description:
Ax-ZSH is a modular configuration system for ZSH. It provides sane defaults and is extendable by plugins.
Ax-ZSH integrates well with Powerlevel10k and other extensions, including plugins compatible with oh-my-zsh.
items.title: ax-zsh

items.description: A minimalist ZSH plugin manager.
items.title: deer

items.description: Dotzsh strives to be platform and version independent. Some functionality may be lost when running under older versions of ZSH, but it should degrade cleanly and allow you to use the same setup on multiple machines of differing OSes without problems.
items.title: dotzsh

items.description: fresh is a tool to source shell configuration (aliases, functions, etc) from others into your own configuration files. We also support files such as ackrc and gitconfig. Think of it as Bundler for your dot files.
items.title: fresh

items.description: gh-source is a plugin manager for people who don't like plugin managers. It's a simple shell function that downloads and installs plugins from GitHub as part of the sourcing step. It's designed to be used with , but it should work with any shell.
items.title: gh-source

items.description: oh-my-zsh is a community-driven framework for managing your ZSH configuration. Includes 120+ optional plugins (rails, , macOS, , , , , MacPorts, etc), over 120 themes to spice up your morning, and an auto-update tool that makes it easy to keep up with the latest updates from the community.
items.title: oh-my-zsh

items.description:
PMS allows you to manage your shell in a way to that helps decrease setup time and increases your productivity. It has support for themes (change the way your shell looks), plugins (adds functionality to your shell), and dotfile management.
The PMS framework also allows you to use the same framework in different shells. Use ZSH on your personal laptop, and use on remote servers. Wanna try ? Go ahead, try out different shells.
items.title: PMS

items.description: Prezto enriches the ZSH command line interface environment with sane defaults, aliases, functions, auto completion, and prompt themes. There are some prezto-specific plugins at https://github.com/belak/prezto-contrib.
items.title: prezto

items.description: Pumice is a lightweight plugin manager for ZSH.
items.title: pumice

items.description:
Most ZSH plugin managers are bloated. They try to do too much - dependency graphs, deferred loading, configuration injection - and in the process, they slow down your shell.
The reality is, most users never use even 80% of these features. is deliberately minimal. All it does is download plugins and update plugins.
items.title: rac

items.description: ryzshrc is a smart, innovative plugin manager like Oh My Zsh, designed to enhance your terminal experience with professional and cool features. It boosts productivity by providing efficient shell management, sleek themes, and powerful plugins. Perfect for developers seeking a modern and intelligent way to work with their terminal
items.title: ryzshrc

items.description: shplug is an easy solution for managing your shell environments. Works with both and . Makes it easy to sync your environment across multiple machines with a repository.
items.title: shplug

items.description:
TheFly is a // plugin manager and env teleporter
Makes your shell env and plugins available everywhere (hosts/users)!
items.title: TheFly

items.description: Toasty is a ZSH framework made to facilitate management, not dictate it.
items.title: Toasty

items.description: uz is a micro plugin manager for ZSH
items.title: uz

items.description: Yazt is a simple ZSH theme manager in maintenance that is compatible with nearly everything. You can use prompts in plugins, mix 'n' match two themes and with a few modifications, you can even use it in .
items.title: yazt

items.description: yzsh is a simple ZSH framework for managing plugins, themes, functions, aliases and environment variables.
items.title: yzsh

items.description: :zap:zap is a minimal ZSH plugin manager.
items.title: zap

items.description: zapack is a basic fast minimal ZSH plugin loader.
items.title: zapack

items.description: zcomet is a minimalistic ZSH plugin manager that gets you to the prompt surprisingly quickly without caching (see the benchmarks). In addition to loading and updating plugins stored in repositories, it supports lazy-loading plugins (further reducing startup time) as well as downloading and sourcing code snippets.
items.title: zcomet

items.description: Zeesh is a cross-platform ZSH framework. It's similar to, but incompatible with, oh-my-zsh. It has a modular plugin architecture making it easy to extend. It has a rich set of defaults, but is designed to be as lightweight as possible.
items.title: zeesh

items.description: zgem is a plugin manager for ZSH that supports loading and updating plugins and themes from git, http and local files.
items.title: zgem

items.description:
Zgen is currently not being actively maintained. I recommend you use the zgenom fork instead, which is actively maintained and continues to get new features and bug fixes.
Zgen is a lightweight plugin manager for ZSH inspired by Antigen. The goal is to have minimal overhead when starting up the shell because nobody likes waiting.
items.title: zgen

items.description:
A lightweight plugin manager for ZSH that is a fork that extends the brilliant zgen and provides more features and bugfixes while being fully backwards compatible.
To keep loading fast during new terminal sessions, generates a static file which does nothing but source your plugins and append them to your .
This minimizes startup time by not having to execute time consuming logic (plugin checking, updates, etc) during every shell session's startup. The downside is that you have to refresh the init script manually with whenever you update your plugin list in your .
Zgenom can load oh-my-zsh-compatible and prezto-compatible plugins and themes, and will automagically plugins for you when you add them to your plugin list.
items.title: zgenom

items.description: zilsh is a ZSH config system that aims to appeal more to power-users and follow the simplistic approach of vim-pathogen.
items.title: zilsh

items.description: Zim is a ZSH configuration framework with blazing speed and modular extensions.
items.title: zim

items.description: zit is a plugin manager for ZSH. It is minimal because it implements the bare minimum to be qualified as a plugin manager: it allows the user to install plugins from repositories (and repositories only, that's why the name), source plugins and update them. It does not implement fancy functions like cleanup of removed plugins, automatic compilation of installed plugins, alias for oh-my-zsh/prezto/other ZSH frameworks, building binaries, manipulation and others.
items.title: zit

items.description: zlugin is a very lightweight ZSH plugin manager.
items.title: zlugin

items.description: Zoppo is the crippled configuration framework for ZSH. As an Italian saying goes: "chi va con lo zoppo, impara a zoppicare", we realized we were walking with a cripple and are now going to become crippled ourselves.
items.title: zoppo

items.description: Zpacker is a lightweight ZSH plugin & theme management framework.
items.title: zpacker

items.description:
zpico is a minuscule ZSH package manager. No frills, no bloat, just 2 kB of 100% ZSH code, providing complete package management for your ZSH environment.
ZSH package managers are abundant, but most are bloated, slow or have excessive requirements. On top of that, more than a few have been abandoned for years. Zpico does not seek to be the best of the best, rather to balance functionality against a tiny, fast footprint.
items.title: zpico

Many of the themes here use special glyphs for things like displaying a branch icon. You'll need to use a Nerd Font or a Powerline-compatible font in your terminal program or you'll see ugly broken boxes where the symbols should be.

items.description: I recommend zgenom if you don't already have a preferred ZSH framework. It adds minimal overhead during shell session startup because it generates a load script only when you change your plugin list, and that load script is sourced during startup instead of being recalculated every time.
items.title: Installation
